benefits.title: High dose vitamin C supplementation increases the Th1/Th2 cytokine secretion ratio, but decreases eosinophilic infiltration in bronchoalveolar lavage fluid of ovalbumin-sensitized and challenged mice.
benefits.summary: High dose vitamin C supplementation decreases eosinophilic infiltration and modulates the Th1/Th2 balance, potentially attenuating allergic inflammation.
benefits.journal: Journal of agricultural and food chemistry

benefits.title: Vitamin C for the critically ill: Is the evidence strong enough?
benefits.summary: Vitamin C supplementation of 3g/d intravenously reduces incidence of multiorgan failure and duration of mechanical ventilation in critically ill patients.

benefits.title: Limited evidence for a beneficial effect of vitamin C supplementation on biomarkers of cardiovascular diseases: an umbrella review of systematic reviews and meta-analyses.
benefits.summary: Vitamin C supplementation has limited effects on cardiovascular risk factors, but some subgroups may be more responsive, such as older people, obese individuals, and those with lower vitamin C status.

benefits.title: Vitamin C and Infections
benefits.summary: Vitamin C may alleviate or prevent infections caused by bacteria, viruses, and protozoa, and shorten the duration of colds.

benefits.title: Vitamin C and Heart Health: A Review Based on Findings from Epidemiologic Studies
benefits.summary: Vitamin C may slightly improve endothelial function and lipid profiles in some groups, especially those with low plasma vitamin C levels.

benefits.title: Two Faces of Vitamin C—Antioxidative and Pro-Oxidative Agent
benefits.summary: Vitamin C treatment is effective in cancer prevention, maintaining redox balance in the central nervous system, and has radioprotective properties.

benefits.title: Improving the nutritional value of crops through enhancement of L-ascorbic acid (vitamin C) content: rationale and biotechnological opportunities.
benefits.summary: Vitamin C has been implicated in the prevention of chronic diseases like heart disease, stroke, cancer, and neurodegenerative diseases.
benefits.journal: Journal of agricultural and food chemistry

benefits.title: Vitamin C and Cardiovascular Disease: An Update
benefits.summary: Vitamin C's antioxidant properties have potential beneficial effects in cardiac and vascular disorders, including coronary heart disease, heart failure, hypertension, and cerebrovascular diseases.

benefits.title: Vitamin B₂ Sensitizes Cancer Cells to Vitamin-C-Induced Cell Death via Modulation of Akt and Bad Phosphorylation.
benefits.summary: Vitamin C and vitamin B2 combination achieves synergistic anticancer activity by inhibiting Akt and Bad phosphorylation in cancer cells.
benefits.journal: Journal of agricultural and food chemistry

benefits.title: Effect of Vitamin C Supplements on Physical Performance
benefits.summary: Vitamin C may reduce muscle damage, immune dysfunction, and fatigue, but doses of 0.2gd1 may impair training adaptations.

side effects.title: The Effect of Intravenous Vitamin C on Cancer- and Chemotherapy-Related Fatigue and Quality of Life
side effects.summary: Intravenous vitamin C alleviates cancer- and chemotherapy-related symptoms like fatigue, insomnia, loss of appetite, nausea, and pain, improving overall health and quality of life.

side effects.title: The influence of large doses of vitamin C on psychological functioning
side effects.summary: Large doses of vitamin C can lead to decreased reaction times and psychomotor coordination.

side effects.title: High dose vitamin C induced methemoglobinemia and hemolytic anemia in glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency.
side effects.summary: High dose vitamin C can induce methemoglobinemia and hemolytic anemia in patients with G6PD deficiency.
side effects.journal: The American journal of emergency medicine

side effects.title: Vitamin C—Sources, Physiological Role, Kinetics, Deficiency, Use, Toxicity, and Determination
side effects.summary: High doses of vitamin C can cause oxalate renal stones in some susceptible patients.

side effects.title: Negative influence on human health for use and frequent i nadequado vitamin C
side effects.summary: Excess vitamin C can cause vomiting, diarrhea, stomach pains, moderate or severe headaches, destruction of red blood cells, and increase the risk of blood diseases.

side effects.title: Relief from cancer chemotherapy side effects with pharmacologic vitamin C.
side effects.summary: Vitamin C administration (50 g/session) led to dramatic decreases in fatigue, insomnia, and increased cognitive functioning without adverse side effects.

side effects.title: Deliberate Vitamin C S elf-Administration by the Public *
side effects.summary: Side effects of Vitamin C include sleepiness, soreness of the tongue, constipation, and abdominal symptoms.

side effects.title: Hyperoxalosis Secondary to Intravenous Vitamin C Administration as a Non-Allopathic Treatment for Cancer
side effects.summary: Intravenous high-dose vitamin C can cause hyperoxalosis of the kidney, a significant complication of treatment, and can contribute to death.

side effects.title: Large scale studies with vitamin C.
side effects.summary: Vitamin C reduces disability due to common colds and other winter illnesses, but no clear evidence of harmful side-effects has been seen.

dosage.title: Vitamin C elevates red blood cell glutathione in healthy adults.
dosage.summary: Vitamin C supplementation (500 mg/d) maintains reduced glutathione concentrations in blood and improves the overall antioxidant protection capacity of blood.
dosage.journal: The American journal of clinical nutrition

dosage.title: Effects of vitamin C supplementation on antioxidants and lipid peroxidation markers in elderly subjects with type 2 diabetes.
dosage.summary: 0.5 and 1g of vitamin C per day significantly increased cellular reduced glutathione levels and vitamin E content of LDL in elderly patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus.

dosage.title: Plasma-Saturating Intakes of Vitamin C Confer Maximal Antioxidant Protection to Plasma
dosage.summary: The antioxidant protection afforded by short-term vitamin C supplementation is maximal at the 500–1000 mg dosage range.
dosage.journal: Journal of the American College of Nutrition

dosage.title: Hemochromatosis and Vitamin C
dosage.summary: Do not exceed a daily dose of 200 mg of vitamin C for patients with hemochromatosis, and start treatment only after an initial month of Desferal infusion.

dosage.title: Adjuvant Vitamin C in critically ill patients undergoing renal replacement therapy: What’s the right dose?
dosage.summary: The optimal dosage strategy for intravenous vitamin C in critically ill patients is unclear, with dosages varying from 50 mg/kg/day to 1584 mg/kg/day.

dosage.title: An update of the effects of vitamins D and C in critical illness
dosage.summary: Vitamin C dosages in critically ill patients should be 100-200 mg/d for parenteral nutrition, but needs may be as high as 2-3 g/d in acutely ill patients.

dosage.title: The effect on winter illness of large doses of vitamin C.
dosage.summary: The optimum daily dose of vitamin C is less than 250 mg, except possibly at the time of acute illness, when a larger daily intake may be beneficial.

dosage.title: Does short-term vitamin C reduce cardiovascular risk in type 2 diabetes?
dosage.summary: Vitamin C dosages in this study were low-dose (250 mg/day), medium-dose (500 mg/day), and high-dose (1,000 mg/day).
dosage.journal: Endocrine practice : official journal of the American College of Endocrinology and the American Association of Clinical Endocrinologists

dosage.title: The study of vitamin C supply in surgical patients
dosage.summary: Vitamin C can be safely and effectively supplied in 500 mg doses a day to surgical patients, while 1 000 mg/day is superfluous.

dosage.title: Levels of antioxidant nutrients in plasma and low density lipoproteins: a human volunteer supplementation study.
dosage.summary: A daily dosage of 250 mg of vitamin C is recommended for optimal uptake in plasma and LDL.
